meaning: To initiate conversation in a social setting
example: She told a joke to break the ice at the meeting.
origin: From old sailing ships breaking ice to create a path

meaning: To endure a painful situation with courage
example: He had to bite the bullet and admit his mistake.
origin: From battlefield surgery without anesthesia (biting a bullet to endure pain).

meaning: To go to bed or sleep
example: I'm really tired, I'm going to hit the sack.
origin: Refers to sleeping on a sack filled with hay in olden times.

idiom: Let the cat out of the bag
meaning: To reveal a secret accidentally
example: He let the cat out of the bag about her surprise party.
origin: From medieval markets—dishonest sellers would replace a pig with a cat in a bag.

meaning: Something that happens very rarely
example: I eat fast food only once in a blue moon.
origin: Refers to rare second full moons in a calendar month.

meaning: Feeling sick or unwell
example: I'm not coming today, I feel under the weather.
origin: Originates from sailors feeling ill during storms.

idiom: The ball is in your court
meaning: It's your decision now
example: I've done my part, now the ball is in your court.
origin: From tennis — it's your turn to respond.

meaning: In agreement or understanding
example: We're finally on the same page about the project.
origin: Refers to reading the same part of a script or book.

idiom: Kill two birds with one stone
meaning: To solve two problems at once
example: I killed two birds with one stone by shopping while waiting for him.
origin: From an old proverb about efficiency.

meaning: Worrying about something that cannot be changed
example: There's no use crying over spilled milk.
origin: From old European proverbs, warning not to be upset over small losses.

meaning: Something that seems bad but turns out good
example: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise.
origin: From 18th-century proverbs.

meaning: The final problem in a series of issues
example: Her rude comment was the last straw.
origin: Old idiom from camel-loading tales.

idiom: Cost an arm and a leg
meaning: Very expensive
example: That car cost me an arm and a leg!
origin: Possibly WWII origin (soldiers' injuries).

idiom: Hit the nail on the head
meaning: Describe something accurately or do something exactly right
example: You hit the nail on the head with your analysis.
origin: Carpentry-related phrase.

meaning: Work late into the night
example: She burned the midnight oil to finish the report.
origin: From oil lamps used before electricity.

meaning: Join a popular trend or activity
example: Everyone's jumping on the fitness bandwagon.
origin: Originated in U.S. political rallies.

meaning: Give up or quit
example: He threw in the towel after trying for years.
origin: From boxing (literally throwing towel to quit).

meaning: Avoid taking sides in a dispute
example: She sat on the fence during the debate.
origin: Political metaphor from 1800s.

meaning: Pursuing a false lead or mistaken belief
example: If you think I did it, you're barking up the wrong tree.
origin: From hunting dogs barking at empty trees.

meaning: To die
example: He kicked the bucket at age 90.
origin: Possibly from hanging or slaughter practices.

meaning: Something very easy to do
example: That test was a piece of cake.
origin: 20th-century American slang.

meaning: Very common and of little value
example: Cheap plastic toys are a dime a dozen.
origin: U.S. 1800s (cheap goods).

meaning: Joke or tease someone playfully
example: Don't worry — I'm just pulling your leg.
origin: Possibly old thieves' slang.

meaning: Start again after a failure
example: The plan didn't work — back to the drawing board.
origin: WWII engineering jargon.

meaning: Wish someone good luck (especially before a performance)
example: Break a leg before your audition!
origin: Theater superstition (opposite to avoid jinx).

meaning: Avoid saying something directly
example: Stop beating around the bush and tell me the truth.
origin: Hunting metaphor (flushing birds).

meaning: Nervousness before a big decision or event
example: She got cold feet before the wedding.
origin: Possibly from military desertions.

meaning: In trouble
example: He found himself in hot water after missing the deadline.
origin: From ancient punishments or risky situations.

meaning: Reveal secret information
example: He spilled the beans about the merger.
related_idiom: Let the cat out of the bag
origin: Possibly from voting systems in Ancient Greece.

meaning: To leave or begin a journey
example: We need to hit the road early tomorrow.
origin: American travel slang.

meaning: Do more than what is expected
example: She always goes the extra mile for her customers.
origin: Biblical origin (Roman law).

meaning: Do something cheaply or carelessly
example: They cut corners when building the house.
origin: From racing or construction.

meaning: To achieve a perfect or very high score on a test or exam
example: She studied for weeks and managed to ace her final exam.
origin: From the ace card, representing excellence

meaning: To study hard
example: I have a big exam tomorrow, so I need to hit the books tonight.
origin: From literally opening and studying books

meaning: To memorize something perfectly
example: Students were required to learn the poem by heart for the recitation.
origin: From knowing something so well it's ingrained in one's memory

meaning: To succeed easily and exceptionally well (in an exam, project, etc.)
example: She studied diligently and passed her final exam with flying colors.
origin: From flags being raised to show success

meaning: To stay up all night studying or working on a project
example: I had to pull an all-nighter to finish my research paper before the deadline.
origin: From staying up for an entire night

meaning: A student who is favored by the teacher
example: He always sat in the front row and answered every question, earning him the title of teacher's pet.
origin: From a student receiving preferential treatment from a teacher

meaning: Something that makes one think seriously; interesting information to consider
example: The professor's lecture on artificial intelligence gave us a lot of food for thought.
origin: From providing mental nourishment

meaning: To begin something before others; to gain an advantage by starting early
example: She got a head start on her research project over the summer.
origin: From beginning before others in a race

meaning: Refers to the basic skills of reading, writing, and arithmetic (traditionally taught in elementary school)
example: Modern education emphasizes more than just the three R's.
origin: Abbreviation for Reading, 'Riting, 'Rithmetic

meaning: Someone who learns new things quickly and easily
example: The new intern is a quick study; she picked up all the procedures in just a few days.
origin: Describes someone who learns rapidly

idiom: Every cloud has a silver lining
meaning: Every difficult or unpleasant situation has some hidden advantage or good aspect.
example: Losing that job was tough, but it led me to a better opportunity, proving every cloud has a silver lining.
origin: From the appearance of clouds with the sun behind them

meaning: Raining very heavily.
example: I can't go out now; it's raining cats and dogs!
origin: Unclear origin, possibly from old Norse mythology or slang

meaning: Not difficult to understand or do.
example: Learning to use this software is not rocket science; anyone can do it.
origin: Rocket science is considered a very complex field

idiom: Like two peas in a pod
meaning: Very similar in appearance, behavior, or interests.
example: My brother and I are like two peas in a pod; we enjoy all the same hobbies.
origin: From the appearance of peas in a single pod

meaning: A very short period of time; almost instantly.
example: The magician made the card disappear in the blink of an eye.
origin: From the quick movement of an eyelid

meaning: Excellent; superb; wonderful (an older, somewhat humorous idiom).
example: Her new dress is absolutely the cat's pajamas!
origin: From early 20th-century American slang, indicating something fashionable and desirable

meaning: Clumsy or awkward with one's hands.
example: I'm all thumbs when it comes to needlework; I can never thread the needle.
origin: From the idea of having only thumbs, which are not dexterous for fine work

meaning: Thirteen.
example: I ordered a dozen donuts, but they gave me a baker's dozen.
origin: Bakers historically added an extra item to a dozen to avoid being accused of shortchanging customers

meaning: Having very poor eyesight.
example: Without my glasses, I'm as blind as a bat.
origin: Bats are commonly perceived as having poor vision (though they use echolocation)

meaning: To stop yourself from saying something that you want to say, because it would be rude or inappropriate.
example: I had to bite my tongue to stop myself from criticizing her idea.
origin: From physically preventing oneself from speaking

meaning: A possession that is useless or troublesome, especially one that is expensive to maintain or difficult to dispose of.
example: That old car became a white elephant; it cost more to fix than it was worth.
origin: From the historical practice of the King of Siam giving white elephants to those he wished to ruin

meaning: To be prone to stealing.
example: The manager suspected someone in the office had sticky fingers after money went missing.
origin: From the idea of things adhering to one's fingers, implying theft

meaning: Gentle and inoffensive; not aggressive or violent.
example: Despite his tough appearance, he wouldn't harm a fly.
origin: From the idea of not being violent even towards a small, insignificant creature

meaning: An apology for using bad language.
example: That was a dreadful, pardon my French, screw-up!
origin: A polite way to apologize for using profanity

meaning: Crazy; insane; behaving in a very foolish way.
example: You want to quit your stable job to travel the world? Are you out of your mind?
origin: From the idea of losing one's sanity

idiom: Have a memory like an elephant
meaning: To have an excellent memory.
example: She never forgets a face; she truly has a memory like an elephant.
origin: Elephants are known for their strong memory

meaning: Not clear at all; very difficult to understand.
example: The instructions for assembling the furniture were as clear as mud.
origin: An ironic phrase, as mud is opaque

meaning: To be the most extreme or astonishing example of something (often used humorously or ironically).
example: His excuse for being late really takes the biscuit; he claimed a unicorn blocked the road!
origin: From competitions where the winner received a cake or biscuit

meaning: To make the best possible effort; to create the best impression.
example: When applying for the scholarship, make sure to put your best foot forward.
origin: From trying to start something in the best way possible

meaning: To learn the basics of a job or activity
example: It took her a few weeks to learn the ropes at her new job.
origin: From sailing, where new sailors had to learn how to handle the ropes

meaning: Very intelligent or clever
example: That student is as bright as a button; she always gets top marks.
origin: Buttons were kept polished and shiny, representing brightness

meaning: Someone or something of high quality or impressive
example: The new teacher is a real class act; students love her lessons.
origin: From theatrical performances of high quality

meaning: A particular philosophy or way of thinking about something
example: There are different schools of thought on how to teach mathematics.
origin: From philosophical and academic traditions

idiom: Burning the candle at both ends
meaning: Working excessively hard, exhausting oneself
example: She's burning the candle at both ends studying for finals.
origin: From literally burning a candle from both ends, making it burn faster

idiom: Rome wasn't built in a day
meaning: Complex tasks take time to complete
example: Learning a new language is difficult; remember, Rome wasn't built in a day.
origin: Refers to the time it took to build the Roman Empire

meaning: Information and learning give you strength and advantage
example: Study hard because knowledge is power in today's world.
origin: From Francis Bacon's philosophical writings

meaning: To think creatively and unconventionally
example: To solve this problem, we need to think outside the box.
origin: From lateral thinking puzzles and creative problem-solving

meaning: Return to fundamental principles
example: When students struggle, sometimes we need to go back to basics.
origin: From returning to core fundamentals in learning

meaning: The rate of progress in learning something new
example: There's a steep learning curve when starting computer programming.
origin: From graphical representation of learning progress over time

meaning: To do something innovative or pioneering
example: This research could break new ground in medical science.
origin: From literally breaking soil for new construction

idiom: Don't count your chickens before they hatch
meaning: Don't assume success before it happens
example: I might get the promotion, but I won't count my chickens before they hatch.
origin: From Aesop's fable about a milkmaid counting future profits

idiom: The early bird catches the worm
meaning: Success comes to those who start early
example: I always arrive early to meetings; the early bird catches the worm.
origin: From the observation that early-rising birds find more food

idiom: Don't put all your eggs in one basket
meaning: Don't risk everything on one venture
example: Invest in different stocks; don't put all your eggs in one basket.
origin: From the risk of carrying all eggs in one container

meaning: What you do is more important than what you say
example: He promised to help, but actions speak louder than words.
origin: Ancient wisdom about the importance of deeds over promises
